White House budget slashes 'countering violent extremism' grants
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The budget proposal unveiled by the White House on
Tuesday cut all funding to a Department of Homeland Security program known
as “countering violent extremism,” which provides grants to communities to
The program, whose roots go back to the Obama administration, has come
under scrutiny by the Trump administration and some congressional
Republicans who favor law enforcement, rather than community outreach, to
fight what they see as a growing Islamic extremist threat.
At the beginning of the administration, some White House and DHS officials
considered changing the name of the program to “countering Islamic
extremism,” and refocusing the funding only on grants that dealt with the
Islamic community, not other communities that may have extremist views
The Trump administration has frozen $10 million in grants allocated at the
end of the Obama administration under the countering violent extremism
program and has yet to reallocate the funds.
The funding cuts proposed by the budget would reduce the $50 million
currently allocated for the program down to zero for fiscal year 2018.
